Start: ^Where were you night of the murder?

c-0: ^Well sir, while I was busying myself by cleaning the Admiral's duelling pistols when I heard a commotion in the Admiral's study. There, I overheard the Admiral and Lady Hold engaged in a- difficult conversation. Lady Hold left the Admiral's office quite distraught.
^I escorted Lady Hold to her chambers and comforted her, after which I returned to my own quarters.

Night_Of_Murder: ^Did you hear what Charles and Theodosia were arguing about?
^Why were you cleaning the Admiral's duelling pistols?
^Do you think Avery could have been involved in the Admiral's death somehow?

c-0:
^Well sir, I was sleeping quite soundly last night, when I suddenly woke to the sound of young Master Avery screaming.

^I was in such an awful rush to find the poor boy that- to my shame- I ran down the main staircase while still in my nightgown.

^I'm afraid by the time I found him, poor Avery had already seen the Amdiral's-

^By which I mean that the Admiral was-

^I'm sorry, sir, it's too horrid to say.
c-1: ^Lady Hold greatly has often told me she thinks it is vulgar when servants make excessive use of their senses, so I thought it rude to listen.
c-2:
^Well, before he- expired- Admiral Hold requested that I prepare his duelling pistols for him.

^He seemed to imply that he would have some use for them upon your arrival, though what use exactly, he didn't specify.
c-3: ^ ^Young Master Avery is a child! Hardly even eight years of age! To imply that he could have had a hand in good Admiral Hold's- in his- ^Well it's simply unthinkable! And I am quite sure the noble profession of journalism would never engage in wild, unproven speculation! ^It is certainly something I would take no pleasure in reading.

Relationship: ^How long have you worked for the Hold family?
^Did the Admiral ever treat you poorly?

c-0: ^Well sir, I came to Wenchwatch Hall seven years ago, shortly after the birth of young Master Avery.
c-1:
^Oh no sir, Admiral Hold was very respectful, a perfect gentleman.

^I only wish that his younger brother took after the Admiral in that regard. He can at times be a bit-
